Variational Bayes survival analysis for unemployment modelling
summary: The proposed model uses a deep artificial neural network (ANN) as a non-linear hazard function that is used to determine the employment probability over time for each individual on the record.

title: Structuring the scattered literature on algorithmic profiling in the case of unemployment through a systematic literature review
summary: The literature review shows that APPES constitutes an emerging field of research encompassed by four strands and associated research disciplines, thus suggesting that the practices and effects of algorithmic profiling are multidimensional and dynamic.
venue: International journal of sociology and social policy

title: Predicting the probability of long-term unemployment and recalibrating Ireland's Statistical Profiling Model

title: (in) Accuracy in Algorithmic Profiling of the Unemployed – An Exploratory Review of Reporting Standards
summary: It is demonstrated that the current method of reporting a single measure for accuracy (usually a percentage) inflates the capabilities of the technology in a peculiar way, and so falsely identify those who prove to be frictionally unemployed as likely to be LTU, having important implications for the effectiveness of spending on ALMPs.

title: Machine Learning and Subjective Assessments by Unemployed Workers and Their Caseworkers
summary: The results suggest that caseworker assessments contain information not captured by the machine learning algorithm, and random-forest machine learning methods are used to predict individual LTU.
authors: G. J. Berg,Max Kunaschk,Julia Lang,G. Stephan,Arne Uhlendorﬀ

title: Using Machine Learning to Create an Early Warning System for Welfare Recipients
summary: Predictive models of income support receipt intensities for any payment enrolee in the Australian social security system between 2014 and 2018 are developed to improve the detection of long-term income support recipients accruing a welfare cost nearly AUD 1 billion higher than individuals identified in the current system.

title: Do Red-Flagged Clients Exit Social Assistance Earlier than Others? The Case of the Finnish Social Assistance System
Fairness in vulnerable attribute prediction on social media
summary: The results show that careful assessment of fairness metrics should be considered when AI models are employed for policymaking, and a framework based on an adaptive threshold for gender is proposed.

title: The stealth legitimization of a controversial policy tool: Statistical profiling in French Public Employment Service
Algorithmic Profiling in Public Employment Services: a Systematic Review on the Effects on Caseworkers and Jobseekers
summary: The understanding of the role of digital tools for the work of street-level bureaucrats and for citizens is enhanced by systematically identifying and compiling a differentiated picture of the impact and risks of algorithmic profiling.

title: Electric Dreams of Welfare in the 4th Industrial Revolution: An Actor-network Investigation and Genealogy of an Algorithm

Statistical profiling in public employment services
summary: An overview on profiling tools currently used throughout the OECD is presented, considerations for the development of such tools, and some insights into the latest developments such as using “click data” on job searches and advanced machine learning techniques are presented.
venue: OECD Social, Employment and Migration Working Papers

title: Implications of technological change and austerity for employability in urban labour markets
summary: A critical review of the literature on ICT and its relation to, and implications for, employability in a context of austerity is presented and those aspects of employability where ICT plays a key role are highlighted.

title: Using Artificial Intelligence to classify Jobseekers: The Accuracy-Equity Trade-off
summary: It is argued that it is critical that policymakers and caseworkers understand the inherent trade-offs of profiling models, and consider the limitations when integrating these models in daily operations, and a graphical tool is developed to visualize the accuracy-equity trade-off in order to facilitate policy discussions.

title: Fairness in Algorithmic Profiling: A German Case Study
summary: This study compares and evaluates statistical models for predicting job seekers' risk of becoming long-term unemployed with respect to prediction performance, fairness metrics, and vulnerabilities to data analysis decisions, and highlights that different classification policies have very different fairness implications.
authors: C. Kern,Ruben L. Bach,H. Mautner,F. Kreuter

title: How to Optimize the Job Search Process: Development and Validation of the Job Search Quality Scale
authors: Edwin A. J. van Hooft,Greet van Hoye,Sarah M van den Hee

title: Algorithmic Tools in Public Employment Services: Towards a Jobseeker-Centric Perspective
summary: It is argued that the limitations and risks of current systems cannot be addressed through minor adjustments but require a more fundamental change to the role of PES.
venue: Conference on Fairness, Accountability and Transparency
authors: Kristen M. Scott,Sonja Mei Wang,Milagros Miceli,Pieter Delobelle,Karolina Sztandar-Sztanderska,Bettina Berendt

The Work Profiler: Revision and maintenance of a profiling tool for the recently unemployed in the Netherlands
authors: Martijn A. Wijnhoven,E. Dusseldorp,M. Guiaux,Harriët Havinga

title: “We try to empower them” - Exploring Future Technologies to Support Migrant Jobseekers
summary: A software-based project is proposed that expands existing job taxonomies into a coordinated resource combining job characteristics, required competencies, and soft skills to support multiple informational tools for jobseekers.
venue: Conference on Fairness, Accountability and Transparency
authors: Sonja Mei Wang,Kristen M. Scott,Margarita Artemenko,Milagros Miceli,Bettina Berendt

title: The impact of modeling decisions in statistical profiling
summary: This work evaluates regression and machine-learning models for predicting job-seekers’ risk of becoming long-term unemployed using German administrative labor market data and shows that training an accurate prediction model is just one element in a series of design and modeling decisions, each having notable effects that span beyond predictive accuracy.
authors: Ruben L. Bach,Christoph Kern,H. Mautner,Frauke Kreuter

title: When Small Decisions Have Big Impact: Fairness Implications of Algorithmic Profiling Schemes
summary: It is shown that despite achieving high prediction performance on average, profiling models can be considerably less accurate for vulnerable social subgroups, and called for rigorous auditing processes before such models are put to practice.
authors: C. Kern,Ruben L. Bach,H. Mautner,F. Kreuter
